children.subject: Typically least squares and OMP.
What's going to be taught in the third module of 16a?

My experience was that 16B's workload was significantly higher than that of 16A. This may have been due to the fact that I had some prior linear algebra experience and so I only had to learn circuits for 16A while 16B only covered stuff I had never seen before. I think most people spent more (3+) hours on their 16B weekly homeworks than 16A although I can't know for sure.
16B is definitely higher, especially the labs. In my experience they usually took at least 2 hours (usually closer to 2.5), and I had to stay late a couple of times during the robot project.
What is the workload of 16B compared to 16A, in terms of hours and difficulty? Thanks
16A doesn't require 1b knowledge, so you can take them concurrently
If I still need credit for Math 1B, is it recommended that I take 1B during my first semester and take 16A my second?
They opened on Monday. Your lab may be full if you are still on the waitlist.
When will 16A seats be open? I haven't gotten pushed off the WL yet, but the seats are now unreserved.
yep, if your friend knows 54-level linear algebra and self-studies the relevant circuits bits from 16A; worked fine for me.
Is it possible to take EE 16B without EE 16A? Asking for a friend.

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs-lowerdiv

"Students who completed Math 54 with a passing letter grade, have a good background in circuits or self-studied that material in advance, and reviewed the EECS 16A homeworks with no significant difficulty completing them, should take EECS 16B."
If I have taken Math 54, can I directly enroll in EECS 16B or it is better (or required) to have an instructor to assess my knowledge about Math 54 and the latter part of EECS16A?

The classes have some overlap, and I would say 70 helped more for 16B than 16B helped for 70 when I was taking both courses at the same time. If you have limited math experience (no extracurricular math related things), 16B will be helpful to take before 70. I'd say 16B starts getting more math and theory heavy in the middle to end of the course, which really starts helping for 70, but if you're already taking 70, by that point of the course you will be comfortable enough with 70.
will EE16B still be helpful for cs70 if we take them at the same time?
Will time conflicts for lecture be allowed for 16b in the Fall?
I totally agree with you!

I think Professor Ranade meant there is no implicit need to take Math 54 (meaning it's not a necessity for every CS/EECS major to take it). There are plenty of CS career paths that don't require such mathematical rigor, and labeling Math 54 as an absolute necessity is a bit disingenuous, given that 16A/B are enough for many.

Sure, but I feel this post is not referring to every CS/EECS major, but rather to the ones that are interested in a career path that involves linear algebra in a good extent (ML, computer graphics, robotics, and many more) and trying to give a heads up to those students to seriously consider taking MATH 54 or MATH 110 or EECS 127, since the linear algebra portion of EECS16AB on its own will just not be enough.
Agreed.

“There is no need for a CS/EECS student to take Math 54”.  As a student who took math 54 (in community college) before taking EE16a and math 110 concurrently with 16a before 16b, I respectfully disagree with this advice.

The EE 16ab series is not a course in linear algebra. It is a course that teaches you how to think like an engineer and design systems, using the tools of linear algebra to tackle challenging real-world problems in signal processing, circuit design, machine learning, information processing, and robotics/control theory.

There is still tremendous value in taking a traditional, axiom-based linear algebra course like Math 54 or 110. This will not only help you understand the concepts at a deeper and more intuitive level, but it will serve you better in the long run.  Don't get me wrong—EE16ab were incredible classes and a lot of fun for me, and I definitely learned a lot from them. The homework problems challenge you to think in new ways, and the labs and iPython notebooks are really cool (they complement the material well, too). The professors who regularly teach these courses are also really good. However, as engineering courses, I feel like they lack the mathematical rigor that you can get from a more math-heavy course in Linear Algebra.

The approach taken in EE16ab is top-down: they start by asking questions and formulating problems that can be solved with linear algebra, then recreate the theory needed to solve these problems. The is in contrast to the bottom-up approach taken in math courses, where they introduce vector spaces, inner products, and linear transformations in terms of basic axioms and build up all theorems and key results in a fully rigorous manner, proving everything along the way. This axiomatic approach is highly valuable to developing an intuitive “feel” for linear algebra and getting used to writing mathematical proofs. Furthermore, it allows students to reason with vectors and linear maps as abstract objects rather than just ordered tuples and matrices, which allows one to generalize and apply analogous reasoning in new and unique situations.

There is value in thinking like a mathematician as well as like an engineer. In short, while the EE 16ab courses are incredible courses in their own regard, I don’t think they can (or should) serve as a replacement for a mathematically rigorous linear algebra course like Math 54 or 110. Even though it may not be required for the CS/EECS major, linear algebra is highly useful and applicable, and a traditional linear algebra course will serve you well throughout your academic and professional career.

For freshmen who are entering, I’d strongly recommend taking Math 54 before, or in parallel, with EE 16a. For students who have taken EE 16a/b already, I’d strongly recommend taking Math 110.

history.content:
<md>This post is intended to address some questions we have been receiving about the EECS 16A-16B course series. EECS16AB was specially designed to ramp students up to prepare for courses in machine learning and design and are important classes to set the stage for the rest of your time in the department. As a rough breakdown of the content in the classes:

16A:
Module 1: Introduction to systems and linear algebra
Module 2: Introduction to design and circuit analysis
Module 3: Introduction to machine learning

16B:
Module 1: Differential equations and advanced circuit design
Module 2: Introduction to robotics and control 
Module 3: Introduction to unsupervised machine learning and classification

And answers to some frequently asked questions:

Q1: Should I take EECS16A my first semester at Cal? 
A1: If you have taken an AP calculus class, then the answer is yes! EECS16A has no prerequisites other than calculus and is designed with freshmen and incoming transfer students in mind. It is designed to be taken alongside 61A. Furthermore, we reserve seats for freshmen and incoming transfer students in the class, so you are essentially guaranteed a spot in the class your first year. It will be harder to get into the class as an upperclassman. 

Q2: Should I take EECS 16A and EECS 16B before or after CS 70? 
A2: EECS16A and 16B were specifically designed to help ease the transition to CS70 for incoming students. These classes provide an introduction to proofs and the kind of mathematical thinking that is very useful in a class like CS70. We recommend you take 16AB before taking CS70, this should help you have an easier time in CS 70.

Q3: Should I take MATH 54 before taking EECS16A? 
A3: EECS 16A is designed to be taken without any prerequisites, so there is no need to take MATH 54 before EECS 16A. EECS 16AB teaches linear algebra with the intent of preparing you for courses like EECS 127 (Optimization) and EECS 189 (Machine Learning) and provides engineering and machine learning examples and applications for linear algebra. EECS 16AB also uses Jupyter notebooks and python so you can better connect linear algebra and computation. There is no need for a CS/EECS student to take Math 54.

Note: EECS16A and EECS16B are the same as EE16A and EE16B --- the course numbering recently changed. 

</md>
history.subject: Professor note: FAQs on EECS16A-16B
